p.s: I am writing you in response to the interview with Ayad Akhtar which has only recently been published in Guernica Magazine.
I read the play Disgraced written by Ayad Akhtar and am a student growing up in Germany.
In the following I am commenting on faith being ones main identity marker.
I can completely understand AkhtarsAkhtar's point talking about the generalization of Muslims after 9/11.
Racial profiling occuring often in the USA is one subtopic.
In Disgraced Amir, the protagonist, talks about security at airports.
He says he knows that they are looking for him because the next terror attack will come from somebody like him.
So even Amir, an apostate coming from Pakistan, generalizes himself.
It does not matter that he feels American and is a part of this society with a high paid job.
The only thing that matters at airports (e.g.) is that he looks Muslim.
Islam is also kind of different when comparing it to Jewry.
As it is mentioned in Disgraced Muslims have to fight for their religion to trullytruely believe in it.
The values and worths Amir has been brought up with are resulting in a feeling of Islamic unity as too 9/11.
Amir mentions that [they] were finally winning including himself using the expression we.
Jory is an example for the contrary opinion about faith being one's main identity marker responding to Amir he is an American.
I also see a big problem in generalizing a person into his religion only.
This is often a reason for xenophobia in this topic islamophobia and racism.
This racism is represented as in the restaurant scene of Disgraced as well.
I often see discrimination or racism because of prejudices in my everyday life.
Even in the school represented by a teacher asking one class mate if she has a German ID-card just because she was black.
This is just one exempleexample, one can see it also in the train or even in a restaurant.
Prejudices just because of an outward appearance are everywhere in the world.
To come to a conclusion I really think that our society, better the whole humanity, should forget their prejudices just because of an outward experience.
A human is more than his skin colour or his faith so it shouldn't be his main identity marker.
PS: I really enjoyed watching your interview with Ayad Akhtar and hope to gave you an alternative on the topic.
